page.title: 05THE SHORE ANGMERING ON SEA.
page.content: Lugworms At low tide local fishermen dig between the cast and nearby hole to find lugworms. By doing this they expose the U-shaped burrow in which they live. The bristly, greenish body can be found with its thin tail nearest to the funnel shaped hole. When moist, decaying seaweed and pebbles are disturbed,the miniature sandy-grey sandhopper is seen hopping away. This crustacean has its body flattened from side to side. Cuttlefish spawn near the shore in June. Their bodies and eggs are often washed ashore. Once the flesh has rotted the white chalky bone is exposed, which is sometimes given to birds as a source of calcium. Of the many seaweeds found, sea lettuce, bladder wrack and carragreen are the most common.
